statements.name: PROC OPTMILP
statements.description: The OPTMILP procedure is a solver for general mixed integer linear programs (MILPs). † The OPTMILP procedure implements an LP-based branch-and-bound algorithm. This divide-and-conquer approach attempts to solve the original problem by solving linear programming relaxations of a sequence of smaller subproblems. The OPTMILP procedure also implements advanced techniques such as presolving, generating cutting planes, and applying primal heuristics to improve the efficiency of the overall algorithm.

arguments.name: ABSOBJGAP=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion. When the absolute difference between the best integer objective and the objective of the best remaining node becomes smaller than the value of number, the procedure stops. The value of number can be any nonnegative number; the default value is 1E–6.

arguments.name: ALLCUTS=
arguments.description: Provides a shorthand way of setting all the cuts-related options in one setting. In other words, ALLCUTS=num is equivalent to setting each of the individual cuts parameters to the same value num.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Generate cutting planes based on a strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable generation of cutting planes.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Use a moderate cut strategy.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Use an aggressive cut strategy.

arguments.name: BASIS=
arguments.description: Specifies one of three available options for generating an initial basis.

arguments.name: CRASH
arguments.description: Generate an initial basis by using crash techniques (Maros 2003). The procedure creates a triangular basic matrix consisting of both decision variables and slack variables. This is the default setting.

arguments.name: SLACK
arguments.description: Generate an initial basis by using all slack variables.

arguments.name: WARMSTART
arguments.description: Start the simplex solvers with a user-specified initial basis. The PRIMALIN= and DUALIN= data sets are required to specify an initial basis.

arguments.name: CONFLICTSEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of conflict search performed by PROC OPTMILP. Conflict search is used to find clauses resulting from infeasible subproblems that arise in the search tree.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Performs conflict search based on a strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables conflict search

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Performs a moderate conflict search

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Performs an aggressive conflict search

arguments.name: CUTCLIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of clique cuts generated by PROC OPTMILP. The CUTCLIQUE= option overrides the ALLCUTS= option. The default value is AUTOMATIC.

arguments.name: CUTOFF=
arguments.description: Cuts off any nodes in a minimization (maximization) problem with an objective value above (below) num. The value of num can be any number; the default value is the positive (negative) number that has the largest absolute value representable in your operating environment.

arguments.name: CUTSFACTOR=
arguments.description: Specifies a row multiplier factor for cuts. The number of cuts added is limited to num times the original number of rows. The value of num can be any nonnegative number less than or equal to 100; the default value is 3.0.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Generate cutting planes based on a strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable generation of cutting planes.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Use a moderate cut strategy.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Use an aggressive cut strategy.

arguments.name: CUTSTRATEGY=
arguments.description: Specifies the overall aggressiveness of the cut generation in the solver. Setting a nondefault value adjusts a number of cut parameters such that the cut generation is basic, moderate, or aggressive compared to the default value.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Generate cutting planes based on a strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: NONE

arguments.name: MODERATE

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE

arguments.name: CUTZEROHALF=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of zero-half cuts that are generated by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Generate cutting planes based on a strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable generation of cutting planes.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Use a moderate cut strategy.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Use an aggressive cut strategy.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input data set corresponding to the MILP model. If this option is not specified, PROC OPTMILP uses the most recently created SAS data set.

arguments.name: DUALOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the output data set to contain the constraint activities.

arguments.name: EMPHASIS=
arguments.description: Specifies a search emphasis option.

arguments.name: BALANCE
arguments.description: Perform a balanced search.

arguments.name: OPTIMAL
arguments.description: Emphasize optimality over feasibility.

arguments.name: FEASIBLE
arguments.description: Emphasize feasibility over optimality.

arguments.name: HEURISTICS=
arguments.description: Enables the user to control the level of primal heuristics applied by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Apply default level of heuristics, similar to MODERATE.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable all primal heuristics.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Apply basic primal heuristics at low frequency.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Apply most primal heuristics at moderate frequency.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Apply all primal heuristics at high frequency.

arguments.name: INTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the amount by which an integer variable value can differ from an integer and still be considered integer feasible. The value of num can be any number between 0.0 and 1.0; the default value is 1E-5.

arguments.name: MAXNODES=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of branch-and-bound nodes to be processed. The value of num can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹-1. The default value is 2³¹-1.

arguments.name: MAXSOLS=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion. If num solutions have been found, then the procedure stops. The value of num can be any positive integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹-1. The default value is 2³¹-1.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum time allowed for PROC OPTMILP to read in the data and find a solution.

arguments.name: NODESEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the node selection strategy option.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Use automatic node selection.

arguments.name: BESTBOUND
arguments.description: Choose the node with the best relaxed objective (best-bound-first strategy).

arguments.name: BESTESTIMATE
arguments.description: Choose the node with the best estimate of the integer objective value (best-estimate-first strategy).

arguments.name: DEPTH
arguments.description: Choose the most recently created node (depth-first strategy).

arguments.name: NTHREADS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of threads to use for multithreaded processing. The branch-and-cut algorithm can take advantage of multicore machines and can potentially run faster when number is greater than 1. The value of number can be any integer between 1 and 256, inclusive. The default is the number of cores on the machine that executes the process or the number of cores permissible based on your installation (whichever is less). The number of simultaneously active CPUs is limited by your installation and license configuration.

arguments.name: OBJSENSE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the MILP model is a minimization or a maximization problem.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: For a minimization problem.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: For a maximization problem.

arguments.name: PRESOLVER=
arguments.description: Specifies a presolve option.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable presolver.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Applies the default level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Performs minimal presolve processing.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Applies a higher level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Applies the highest level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: PRICETYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies one of 5 available pricing strategies for the simplex solvers.

arguments.name: HYBRID
arguments.description: Use a hybrid of Devex and steepest-edge pricing strategies. Available for the primal simplex solver only.

arguments.name: PARTIAL
arguments.description: Use the Dantzig's rule on a queue of decision variables. Optionally, you can specify QUEUESIZE=. Available for the primal simplex solver only.

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: Use the Dantzig's rule on all decision variables.

arguments.name: DEVEX
arguments.description: Use Devex pricing strategy.

arguments.name: STEEPESTEDGE
arguments.description: Use steepest-edge pricing strategy.

arguments.name: PRIMALIN=
arguments.description: Enables you to input an integer feasible solution in a SAS data set. PROC OPTMILP validates both the data set and the solution stored in the data set. If both are valid, then the input solution provides an incumbent solution and a bound for the branch-and-bound algorithm. If either the data set or the solution is not valid, then the PRIMALIN= data are ignored.

arguments.name: PRIMALOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the output data set for the primal solution.

arguments.name: PRINTFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies how often information is printed in the node log. The value of num can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹-1.

arguments.name: PRINTLEVEL2=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of information displayed in the SAS log by the solver, from a short description of presolve information and summary to details at each node.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Turn off all solver-related messages in SAS log.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Display a solver summary after stopping.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Print a solver summary and a node log by using the interval dictated by the PRINTFREQ= option.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Print a detailed solver summary and a node log by using the interval dictated by the PRINTFREQ= option.

arguments.name: PRINTLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether a summary of the problem and solution should be printed.
No ODS tables are produced or printed.
Two ODS (Output Delivery System) tables named "ProblemSummary" and "SolutionSummary" are produced and printed. This is the default.
The "ProblemSummary" and "SolutionSummary" tables are produced and printed along with a third table called "ProblemStatistics."

arguments.name: PRIORITY=
arguments.description: Indicates whether or not to use specified branching priorities for integer variables.

arguments.name: TRUE
arguments.description: Uses priorities when they exist.

arguments.name: FALSE
arguments.description: Ignores variable priorities

arguments.name: PROBE=
arguments.description: Specifies a probing option.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Probing strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable probing.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Use probing moderately.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Use probing aggressively.

arguments.name: RELOBJGAP=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion based on the best integer objective (BestInteger) and the objective of the best remaining node (BestBound).

arguments.name: RESTARTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the strategy for restarting the processing of the root node.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Uses a restarting strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables restarting.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Uses a basic restarting strategy.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Uses a moderate restarting strategy.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Uses an aggressive restarting strategy.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Indicates whether or not to scale the problem matrix.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables scaling.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Scales the matrix as determined by PROC OPTMILP. This is the default.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial seed for the random number generator. Because the seed affects the perturbation in the simplex algorithms, the result might be a different optimal solution and a different solver path, but the effect is usually negligible.

arguments.name: STRONGITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of simplex iterations performed for each variable in the candidate list when using the strong branching variable selection strategy. If you specify the keyword AUTOMATIC, PROC OPTMILP uses the default value; this value is calculated automatically.

arguments.name: STRONGLEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of candidates used when performing the strong branching variable selection strategy. The value of num can be any positive integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹-1. If you specify the keyword AUTOMATIC, PROC OPTMILP uses the default value; this value is calculated automatically.

arguments.name: SYMMETRY=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of symmetry detection. Symmetry detection identifies groups of equivalent decision variables and uses this information to solve the problem more efficiently.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: performs symmetry detection based on a strategy that is determined by PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: disables symmetry detection.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: performs a basic symmetry detection.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: performs a moderate symmetry detection.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: performs an aggressive symmetry detection.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion for minimization (maximization) problems. If the best integer objective is better than or equal to num, the procedure stops. The value of num can be any number; the default value is the negative (positive) number that has the largest absolute value representable in your operating environment.

arguments.name: TIMETYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether CPU time or real time is used for the MAXTIME= option and the _OROPTMILP_ macro variable in a PROC OPTMILP call.

arguments.name: CPU
arguments.description: Specifies that units are in CPU time.

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: Specifies that units are in real time.

arguments.name: VARSEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the rule for selecting the branching variable.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Uses automatic branching variable selection.

arguments.name: MAXINFEAS
arguments.description: Chooses the variable with maximum infeasibility.

arguments.name: MININFEAS
arguments.description: Chooses the variable with minimum infeasibility.

arguments.name: PSEUDO
arguments.description: Chooses a branching variable based on pseudocost.

arguments.name: STRONG
arguments.description: Uses strong branching variable selection strategy.

statements.name: DECOMPMASTERIP
statements.description: For mixed integer linear programming problems, the DECOMPMASTERIP|DECOMPOSITIONMASTERIP|MASTERIP statement controls the (restricted) master problem, which is solved as a MILP with the current set of columns in an effort to obtain an integer-feasible solution.

arguments.name: OPTIMAL
arguments.description: Emphasizes optimality over feasibility

arguments.name: FEASIBLE
arguments.description: Emphasizes feasibility over optimality

arguments.name: FEASTOL=
arguments.description: specifies the tolerance used to check the feasibility of a solution. This tolerance applies both to the maximum violation of bounds on variables and to the difference between the right-hand sides and left-hand sides of constraints. The value of number can be any value between (and including) 1E–4 and 1E–9. The default value is 1E–6.

arguments.name: HEURISTICS=
arguments.description: Controls the level of primal heuristics applied by PROC OPTMILP. This level determines how frequently primal heuristics are applied during the branch-and-bound tree search. It also affects the maximum number of iterations allowed in iterative heuristics. Some computationally expensive heuristics might be disabled by the solver at less aggressive levels. Setting HEURISTICS=NONE does not disable the heuristics that repair an infeasible input solution that is specified in a PRIMALIN= data set.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Apply default level of heuristics, similar to MODERATE.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable all primal heuristics.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Apply basic primal heuristics at low frequency.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Apply most primal heuristics at moderate frequency.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Apply all primal heuristics at high frequency.

arguments.name: INTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the amount by which an integer variable value can differ from an integer and still be considered integer feasible. The value of number can be any number between 0.0 and 1.0; the default value is 1E–5. PROC OPTMILP attempts to find an optimal solution with integer infeasibility less than number. If you assign a value smaller than 1E–10 to number and the best solution found by PROC OPTMILP has integer infeasibility between number and 1E–10, then PROC OPTMILP ends with a solution status of OPTIMAL_COND.

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies how often information is printed in the node log. The value of number can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. The default value is 100. If number is set to 0, then the node log is disabled. If number is positive, then an entry is made in the node log at the first node, at the last node, and at intervals dictated by the value of number. An entry is also made each time a better integer solution is found.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of information displayed in the SAS log by the solver, from a short description of presolve information and summary to details at each node.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Turns off all solver-related messages in the SAS log.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Displays a solver summary after stopping.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Prints a solver summary and a node log by using the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Prints a detailed solver summary and a node log by using the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option.

arguments.name: MAXNODES=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of branch-and-bound nodes to be processed. The value of number can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. The default value is 2³¹ - 1.

arguments.name: MAXSOLS=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion. If number solutions have been found, then the procedure stops. The value of number can be any positive integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. The default value is 2³¹ - 1.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of t seconds of time for reading in the data and performing the optimization process. The value of the TIMETYPE= option determines the type of units used. If you do not specify this option, the procedure does not stop based on the amount of time elapsed. The value of t can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: NODESEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the node selection strategy string or its corresponding value number: –1 AUTOMATIC -- Uses automatic node selection 0 BESTBOUND -- Chooses the node with the best relaxed objective (best-bound-first strategy) 1 BESTESTIMATE -- Chooses the node with the best estimate of the integer objective value (best-estimate-first strategy) 2 DEPTH -- Chooses the most recently created node (depthfirst strategy)

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Use automatic node selection.

arguments.name: BESTBOUND
arguments.description: Choose the node with the best relaxed objective (best-bound-first strategy).

arguments.name: BESTESTIMATE
arguments.description: Choose the node with the best estimate of the integer objective value (best-estimate-first strategy).

arguments.name: DEPTH
arguments.description: Choose the most recently created node (depth-first strategy).

arguments.name: OPTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance used to determine the optimality of nodes in the branch-and-bound tree. The value of number can be any value between (and including) 1E–4 and 1E–9. The default is 1E–6.

arguments.name: PRESOLVER=
arguments.description: Specifies a presolve string or its corresponding value number. –1 AUTOMATIC -- Applies the default level of presolve processing 0 NONE -- Disables presolver 1 BASIC -- Performs minimal presolve processing 2 MODERATE -- Applies a higher level of presolve processing 3 AGGRESSIVE -- Applies the highest level of presolve processing

arguments.name: PRINTLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether a summary of the problem and solution should be printed. If PRINTLEVEL=1, then the ODS (Output Delivery System) tables ProblemSummary, SolutionSummary, and PerformanceInfo are produced and printed. If PRINTLEVEL=2, then these tables are produced and printed along with an additional table called ProblemStatistics. If PRINTLEVEL=0, then no ODS tables are produced or printed. The default value is 1.
Does not produce or print any Output Delivery System (ODS) tables.

arguments.name: PRIORITY=

arguments.name: RELOBJGAP=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion based on the best integer objective (BestInteger) and the objective of the best remaining node (BestBound). The relative objective gap is equal to | BestInteger - BestBound | / (1E-10 + | BestBound |)

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Indicates whether to scale the problem matrix. SCALE= can take either of the values AUTOMATIC (–1) and NONE (0). SCALE=AUTOMATIC scales the matrix as determined by PROC OPTMILP; SCALE=NONE disables scaling. The default value is AUTOMATIC.

arguments.name: STRONGITER=

The value of number can be any positive integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. If you specify the keyword AUTOMATIC or the value –1, PROC OPTMILP uses the default value; this value is calculated automatically.

arguments.description: Syntax: INITPRESOLVER=number | string INITPRESOL=number | string [Used with LP and MILP Algorithms]

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Applies the default level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables presolver.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Performs minimal presolve processing.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Applies a higher level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Applies the highest level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: INTTOL=
arguments.description: [Used with MILP Algorithm]

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of information displayed in the SAS log by the solver, from a short description of presolve information and summary to details at each node.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Turns off all solver-related messages in the SAS log.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Displays a solver summary after stopping.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Prints a solver summary and a node log by using the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Prints a detailed solver summary and a node log by using the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: [Used with LP Algorithm]

arguments.name: MAXNODES=
arguments.description: [Used with MILP Algorithm]

arguments.name: MAXSOLS=
arguments.description: [Used with MILP Algorithm]

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: [Used with LP and MILP Algorithms]

arguments.name: NODESEL=
arguments.description: [Used with MILP Algorithm] Specifies the node selection strategy string or its corresponding value number: –1 AUTOMATIC -- Uses automatic node selection 0 BESTBOUND -- Chooses the node with the best relaxed objective (best-bound-first strategy) 1 BESTESTIMATE -- Chooses the node with the best estimate of the integer objective value (best-estimate-first strategy) 2 DEPTH -- Chooses the most recently created node (depthfirst strategy)

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Use automatic node selection.

arguments.name: BESTBOUND
arguments.description: Choose the node with the best relaxed objective (best-bound-first strategy).

arguments.name: BESTESTIMATE
arguments.description: Choose the node with the best estimate of the integer objective value (best-estimate-first strategy).

arguments.name: DEPTH
arguments.description: Choose the most recently created node (depth-first strategy).

arguments.name: OPTTOL=
arguments.description: [Used with LP and MILP Algorithms]

arguments.name: PRICETYPE=
arguments.description: [Used with LP Algorithm] Specifies a pricing strategy for the primal and dual simplex solvers.

arguments.name: HYBRID
arguments.description: Use a hybrid of Devex and steepest-edge pricing strategies. Available for the primal simplex solver only.

arguments.name: PARTIAL
arguments.description: Use Dantzig’s rule on a queue of decision variables. Optionally, you can specify QUEUESIZE=. Available for the primal simplex solver only.

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: Use Dantzig’s rule on all decision variables.

arguments.name: DEVEX
arguments.description: Use Devex pricing strategy.

arguments.name: STEEPESTEDGE
arguments.description: Use steepest-edge pricing strategy.

arguments.name: PRIMALIN=
arguments.description: Syntax: PRIMALIN=number | string PIN=number | string [Used with MILP Algorithm]

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Ignores the previous solution.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Starts from the previous solution.

arguments.name: PRINTLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether a summary of the problem and solution should be printed. If PRINTLEVEL=1, then the ODS (Output Delivery System) tables ProblemSummary, SolutionSummary, and PerformanceInfo are produced and printed. If PRINTLEVEL=2, then these tables are produced and printed along with an additional table called ProblemStatistics. If PRINTLEVEL=0, then no ODS tables are produced or printed. The default value is 1.
If PRINTLEVEL=0, then no ODS tables are produced or printed.
If PRINTLEVEL=1, then the ODS (Output Delivery System) tables ProblemSummary, SolutionSummary, and PerformanceInfo are produced and printed.
If PRINTLEVEL=2, then these tables are produced and printed along with an additional table called ProblemStatistics.

arguments.name: PROBE=
arguments.description: [Used with MILP Algorithm] Specifies a probing string or its corresponding value number: –1 AUTOMATIC -- Uses the probing strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP 0 NONE -- Disables probing 1 MODERATE -- Uses the probing moderately 2 AGGRESSIVE -- Uses the probing aggressively

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Uses the probing strategy determined by PROC OPTMILP

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables probing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Uses the probing moderately

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Uses the probing aggressively

arguments.name: QUEUESIZE=
arguments.description: [Used with LP Algorithm]

arguments.name: RELOBJGAP=
arguments.description: [Used with MILP Algorithm] Specifies a stopping criterion based on the best integer objective (BestInteger) and the objective of the best remaining node (BestBound). The relative objective gap is equal to | BestInteger - BestBound | / (1E-10 + | BestBound |)

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: [Used with LP and MILP Algorithms] Specifies one of the following scaling options: NONE(0), AUTOMATIC(-1).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable scaling.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Automatically apply scaling procedure if necessary.

arguments.name: STOP_DG=
arguments.description: [Used with LP Algorithm]

arguments.name: STOP_DI=
arguments.description: [Used with LP Algorithm]

arguments.name: STOP_PI=
arguments.description: [Used with LP Algorithm]

arguments.name: STRONGLEN=
arguments.description: [Used with MILP Algorithm]

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: Replace <number> with any positive integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Tells PROC OPTMILP to use the default value; this value is calculated automatically.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: [Used with MILP Algorithm]

arguments.name: TIMETYPE=
arguments.description: [Used with LP and MILP Algorithms]

arguments.name: CPU
arguments.description: Specifies units of CPU time.

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: Specifies units of real time.

arguments.name: VARSEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the rule for selecting the branching variable. [Used with MILP Algorithm]

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Use automatic branching variable selection.

arguments.name: MAXINFEAS
arguments.description: Choose the variable with maximum infeasibility.

arguments.name: MININFEAS
arguments.description: Choose the variable with minimum infeasibility.

arguments.name: PSEUDO
arguments.description: Choose a branching variable based on pseudocost.

arguments.name: STRONG
arguments.description: Use strong branching variable selection strategy.

statements.name: DECOMP
statements.description: The DECOMP|DECOMPOSITION statement controls the overall decomposition algorithm.

arguments.name: ABSOBJGAP=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion for the continuous bound of the decomposition. When the absolute difference between the master objective and the best dual bound falls below the value of number, the decomposition algorithm stops adding columns. The value of number can be any nonnegative number. The default value is the value of the OPTTOL= main solver option.

arguments.name: BLOCKS=
arguments.description: Specifies (for OPTLP and OPTMILP procedures only) the input data set that contains block definitions to be used by the decomposition algorithm if METHOD=USER. To specify blocks in PROC OPTMODEL, use the .block constraint suffix instead.

arguments.name: COMPRESSFREQ=
arguments.description: Removes ineffective columns from the master LP after every number of iterations. The frequency, number, is an integer between 0 and the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. The default value is 0.

arguments.name: INITVARS=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to initialize the columns by using the original cost vector to solve each block.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Disables initializing the columns by using the original cost vector to solve each block.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Enables initializing the columns by using the original cost vector to solve each block.

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies (for MILP problems only) how often to print information in the continuous iteration log. The value of number can be any nonnegative number up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. The default value of number is 10. If number is set to 0, then the iteration log is disabled. If number is positive, then an entry is made in the log at the first iteration, at the last iteration, and at intervals that are dictated by the value of number. An entry is also made each time a better integer solution or improved bound is found.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log by the decomposition algorithm.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Prints the continuous iteration log for the root node at the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option in the DECOMP statement. Prints the branch-and-bound node log at the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= main solver option.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Turns off printing of all of the decomposition algorithm messages to the SAS log.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Prints the continuous iteration log for each branch-andbound node at the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option in the DECOMP statement.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Prints the continuous iteration log and summary information for each iteration of each branch-and-bound node at the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option in the DECOMP statement.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Prints the continuous iteration log and detailed information for each iteration of each branch-and-bound node at the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option in the DECOMP statement.

arguments.name: MASTER_IP_BEG=
arguments.description: Specifies (for MILP problems only) whether the master problem is solved as a MILP with the current set of columns at the beginning of phase II.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Disables solving the master as a MILP at the beginning of phase II.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Enables solving the master as a MILP at the beginning of phase II.

arguments.name: MASTER_IP_END=
arguments.description: Specifies (for MILP problems only) whether the master problem is solved as a MILP with the current set of columns at the end of phase II.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Disables solving the master as a MILP at the end of phase II.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Enables solving the master as a MILP at the end of phase II.

arguments.name: MASTER_IP_FREQ=
arguments.description: Solves the master problem (for MILP problems only) as a MILP with the current set of columns after every number iterations. The frequency, number, is an integer between 0 and the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. The default is 10 in the root node and 0 elsewhere.

arguments.name: MAXBLOCKS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of blocks to allow. If the defined number of blocks exceeds number, the algorithm creates superblocks using a very simple round-robin scheme. The value of number can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: MAXCOLSPASS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of new columns to allow into the master at each pass. This option is disabled on the initial pass if INITVARS=1. The default is 100.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies (for MILP problems only) the maximum number of outer iterations for the decomposition algorithm. The value number can be any integer between 1 and the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. If you do not specify this option, the procedure does not stop based on the number of iterations performed.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of number seconds of time for the decomposition algorithm. The value of the TIMETYPE= main solver option determines the type of units used. If you do not specify this option, the procedure does not stop based on the amount of time elapsed. The value of number can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the decomposition algorithm method. The default is USER if blocks are defined and NETWORK otherwise.

arguments.name: USER
arguments.description: The user defines which rows belong to which blocks (subproblems). In PROC OPTMODEL, use the .block constraint suffix. In PROC OPTLP and PROC OPTMILP, use the BLOCKS= data set instead.

arguments.name: NETWORK
arguments.description: The algorithm attempts to find an embedded network similar to what is described in “The Network Simplex Algorithm”. The weakly connected components of this network are used as the blocks.

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: The algorithm attempts to find a block structure in the constraint matrix. For the current release, METHOD=AUTO finds block-diagonal structure only (not block-angular structures); unless your problem separates into completely independent problems with no linking constraints, this method finds only one block and hence is equivalent to calling the MILP solver directly.

arguments.name: RELOBJGAP=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative objective gap as a stopping criterion. The relative objective gap is based on the master objective (MasterObjective) and the best dual bound (BestBound); it is equal to | MasterObjective - BestBound | / (1E-10 + | BestBound |)

statements.name: PERFORMANCE
statements.description: The PERFORMANCE statement defines performance parameters for multithreaded and distributed computing, passes variables about the distributed computing environment, and requests detailed results about the performance characteristics of a High-Performance Analytics procedure. With the PERFORMANCE statement, you can also control whether the HPNLIN procedure executes in SMP or MPP mode.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: Requests that the procedure produce the Timing ODS table. This table shows a breakdown of the time used in each step of the procedure.

arguments.name: NTHREADS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of threads that a procedure can use. It overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS. The value of number can be any integer between 1 and 256 inclusive. The default value is CPUCOUNT, which sets the thread count to the number that is determined by the SAS system option CPUCOUNT=.

arguments.name: num
arguments.description: Replace <num> with an actual number. The value of number can be any integer between 1 and 256 inclusive. The default value is CPUCOUNT, which sets the thread count to the number that is determined by the SAS system option CPUCOUNT=.

arguments.name: CPUCOUNT
arguments.description: The default value is CPUCOUNT, which sets the thread count to the number that is determined by the SAS system option CPUCOUNT=

arguments.name: PARALLELMODE=
arguments.description: Specifies the parallel processing mode. This mode determines the solution results that are obtained from running the same model with the same option values on the same platform multiple times.

arguments.name: DETERMINISTIC
arguments.description: Requires algorithms to produce the same results every time.

arguments.name: NONDETERMINISTIC
arguments.description: Permits algorithms to produce different solution results. This mode requires less synchronization and might attain better performance than DETERMINISTIC mode.

statements.name: TUNER
statements.description: The TUNER statement invokes the OPTMILP option tuner. The option tuner is a tool that enables you to explore alternative (and potentially better) option configurations for your optimization problems.

arguments.name: GOAL=
arguments.description: Specifies a goal for the option tuner. Every attempt to solve a tuning problem with an option configuration is counted toward the measure specified by the GOAL= option.

arguments.name: GEOMEAN
arguments.description: Minimizes the geometric mean of the solution times of the tuning problems

arguments.name: SUM
arguments.description: Minimizes the sum of the solution times of the tuning problems

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies how often tuning information is printed in the log. The value of number represents the number of problems solved by the tuner between log updates. The value of number can be any nonnegative integer. Specifying LOGFREQ=0 disables log updates. The default is 1.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of information that the tuner displays in the SAS log.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables tuner-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Displays a tuner summary after stopping

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Prints a tuner summary and a tuning log by using the interval dictated by the LOGFREQ= option

arguments.name: MAXCONFIGS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of option configurations that the tuner can evaluate in each problem in the PROBLEMS= data set. The value of number can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. The default is 2³¹ - 1.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum time allowed for the tuner to evaluate option configurations in tuning problems. The default is 36,000 seconds.

arguments.name: OPTIONMODE=
arguments.description: Specifies which set of options to tune.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Uses an option set determined by the tuner

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Solves the problems specified by the PROBLEMS= option without tuning any OPTMILP options

arguments.name: USER
arguments.description: Uses the option set specified by the OPTIONVALUES= option

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: Uses the full set of solver options that are available for tuning

arguments.name: OPTIONVALUES=
arguments.description: Specifies an input data set that contains a list of options to be tuned and ranges of values over which each option should be tuned. You can specify an initial tuning value for each option in the list. If you do not specify a range for a tuning option, the tuner uses the default range of that option. If you do not specify an initial value for a tuning option, the tuner uses the default value of that option. If the option’s default value is not in the specified tuning range, the tuner uses the first (smallest) value in the tuning range. If the data set that is specified by the OPTIONVALUES= option is not found, a default set of options is used.

arguments.name: PROBLEMS=
arguments.description: Specifies the input data set that contains a list of MILP problems to be used for option tuning. This list includes the name of each problem, its library location, and (optionally) its objective sense.

arguments.name: TUNEROUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the output data set that contains detailed results for each tuning problem over all the option configurations that are evaluated.
